key_insight: The paper introduces O-Voxel, a native sparse voxel structure that encodes geometry and appearance together to produce compact, structured latents—enabling generative models to represent complex topology and fine appearance detail more effectively.
problem_solved: Current 3D representations struggle with complex topologies and detailed appearance while being inefficient or non-native for generative modeling; this work provides a representation and latent structure designed to address those limitations.
method: Design O-Voxel: an omni-voxel sparse 3D data structure that stores both geometry and appearance channels natively.
Learn compact, structured latents directly from native 3D data using a training pipeline that maps O-Voxels to/from latent codes.
Use the learned structured latents in a generative framework to synthesize high-fidelity 3D assets with complex topology and detailed appearance.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a more expressive and compact 3D representation for training generative models, improving fidelity, memory efficiency, and downstream tasks like synthesis, editing, and rendering.
visual_elements: Diagram of an O-Voxel block showing sparse grid cells with dual channels for geometry and appearance (color/texture) vs. a standard voxel for comparison.
Pipeline flowchart: native 3D data → O-Voxel encoding → compact structured latent → generative decoder → synthesized 3D asset.
Before/after examples: generation results on assets with complex topology and fine appearance details (baseline vs. O-Voxel latent).
Latent space visualization (e.g., t-SNE/UMAP) illustrating clustering of asset types and compactness of learned representations.
paper_title: Native and Compact Structured Latents for 3D Generation
paper_authors: Jianfeng Xiang, Xiaoxue Chen, Sicheng Xu, Ruicheng Wang, Zelong Lv
